subject: Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Media access and policy; Media access and policy, general; Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: Recordings and broadcasts; Public engagement and education
funder_addr: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, FL United States
description: At a time when more religious literacy would help combat political polarization and disinformation, robust news coverage about religion and faith communities has disappeared along with 2,400 newspapers since 2005. Thirty years ago, the Religion News Association counted 500 members. Today, only a few dozen religion writers are working full-time across the entire country.  Since 1934, Religion News Service (RNS) has helpedÂ ensure stories about faith communities and beliefs are being told. With this proposal, RNS would significantly increase bothÂ reach and impact through a new editorial partnership with National Public Radio (NPR) and local public radio stations across the country. The partnership has the potential to reach 44 million listeners and users across public radio, streaming and digital platforms. RNS would provide unparalleled editorial expertise about religion reporting to public media journalists. Both RNS and NPR would dedicate senior editors, producers and journalists to co-produce audio and/or digital stories.  This project promises to help inform and help more Americans appreciate religious traditions other than their own, providing a major source of religious literacy and new opportunities to support the American tradition of religious pluralism.

description: In a world where local conflict quickly goes global due to social media and misinformation, and where populists and polemicists leverage fear and anger to amass their audience and preserve their influence, religious literacy is needed today more than ever. With this grant,Â CT will continue to expand its savvy, theologically informed journalism and commentary to global, multi-religious cities. This journalism will help our Christian readers better understand not only other Christians in other parts of the planet, but also people of other faiths such as Muslims, Buddhists, and Hindus. This will enable Christian leaders to better guide their constituents on matters of interfaith engagement, creating more effective collaboration for the common good.

title: Clooney Foundation for Justice
subject: Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
strategy: Advocacy; Equal access; Public engagement and education; Program support; Systems reform
recipient_addr: New York City, NY United States
description: The Clooney Foundation for Justice works to support those suffering from mass and systemic injustices, because of who they are, what they do, or where they might find themselves. All over the world, journalists and human rights defenders are detained, prosecuted and jailed. Women, girls and minorities are subject to unfair laws and targeted for abuse. Ukrainians are at the forefront of Russia's aggression, with potential war crimes and crimes against humanity being committed against them. The grantee seeks to address this by: 1) gathering evidence of mass human rights abuses; 2) providing free legal support to victims; and 3) working to ensure that perpetrators are held to account. Established in 2016, the Clooney Foundation for Justice works in more than 40 countries and actively investigates war crimes in Ukraine, monitors sham trials targeting women and journalists, and fights against a global trend of authoritarianism that seeks to punish those who speak truth to power.

title: Center for Michigan
subject: Journalism, news and information; Investigative journalism; Constituency journalism
strategy: Program support; Outreach; Online media; Publications
description: Bridge Michigan's Environment Watch is a digital newspaper published by the Center for Michigan, a nonprofit organization that seeks to make Michigan better through high-quality, nonpartisan journalism and audience engagement. Since its launch in 2011, the online publication has grown dramatically and earned a reputation as one of Michigan’s most trusted news outlets. Bridge Michigan is also one of five nonprofit news outlets that participate in the Great Lakes News Collaborative, a Mott-funded initiative that seeks to improve news coverage of water issues in the region. Bridge Michigan is one of the pillars of the Collaborative. With renewed support, the Center for Michigan will continue to produce in-depth, high-quality, public-service journalism for its Environment Watch publication and the Great Lakes News Collaborative.

description: The Tributary strengthens Northeast Florida's local news landscape, addressing the critical shortfall in investigative journalism and coverage of essential issues like justice, democracy, and barriers to opportunity. This project  will support our team's staff expansion, both in journalism and financial sustainability. Together, they will enhance our capacity to deliver at least 30 in-depth investigative stories annually, develop interactive legislative accountability apps to engage the public, and strengthen media collaborations for broader impact. Expected impacts include policy changes, increased civic engagement, and bolstered support for nonprofit news in Jacksonville. This initiative, backed by The Arthur Vining Davis Foundations, promises to revitalize investigative journalism in our community, making local democracy more transparent and accountable.

recipient: Window to the World Communications Inc
description: WTTW News produces and presents a series of eight to twelve digital stories about art and design in Chicago in conjunction with Art Design Chicago. These longform stories are displayed on news.wttw.com, with four to six featuring as broadcast segments on one of the news-magazine shows Chicago Tonight, Chicago Tonight: Black Voices, and Chicago Tonight: Latino Voices. Potential storylines include coverage of exhibitions, artist interviews, discussions on Chicago's art and design history, and profiles of community art spaces. Together, the stories (shared on artdesignchicago.org) aim to encapsulate the essence of Art Design Chicago by highlighting the city's artistic heritage and its creative communities

title: Reporting on Gun Violence in Chicago: Spotlighting Community Voices, Solutions, and Accountability
subject: Media Content and Platforms; Media Content and Platforms, General; Journalism, news and information; Journalism, news, and information, general
description: Chicagoans affected by gun violence have expressed concern with the media’s coverage of their neighborhoods as being superficial and overly negative. Both residents and researchers have said that prevailing approaches to covering gun violence in Chicago can cause harm. Meanwhile, officials in City Hall and Springfield have often tried to blame gun violence on under-resourced communities, even as those leaders fail to do more to implement and sustain equitable solutions. To combat this, last year we established a bureau in Chicago to challenge misleading narratives and drive more beneficial coverage of the city’s fight against gun violence. Employing an initial team of two native Chicago journalists – one producing accountability and solutions reporting, the other dedicated to community engagement – our investment is equipping The Trace to play an important role in sustaining the civic dialogues critical to building safer communities. Alongside our reporting, this year we engaged our first cohort of gun violence survivors through a Survivor Storytelling Project that empowers Chicago survivors of gun violence to tell their own stories, ensuring that those most impacted by the problem are directly shaping the narrative around shootings. Funding from the Paul M. Angell Foundation will enable us to: * Produce a min. of 12 articles that will compare Chicago’s official response to gun violence to what experts and residents say is really needed; scrutinize the implementation of the new state gun violence prevention package in IL; and distill the findings of research on the root causes and solutions to gun violence so that those insights reach policymakers and the public. * Complete the second year of our Survivor Storytelling Project, which will empower and compensate gun violence survivors to produce their own narratives. * Develop or expand collaborations with diverse Chicago media partners to amplify our impact and ensure we’re reaching communities with the highest need.

description: MinnPost aims to increase accountability of government and public institutions, foster civic engagement and conversations, and illuminate the human lives affected by decision-making in Minnesota.
